about_the_game:
Hello World!! Welcom to my first making game!
A long time ago, from the 70's to early 80's, I had nostalgic memories of loving games that you could play by inserting a coin, so I created a game that feels like that! It's a simple and easy game, so please give it a try!

Story

In 2015, L.Planning suddenly reincarnates into another world.
What awaited them was an unimaginable drop in sales...
Takeru, a sales employee, is now taking on the burden of the suffering and expectations of executives! !

Action

All you have to do is become Takeru-kun and send the quotation request (green box) received from your business partner to the CEO, and the invoice request (red box) to the CFO.
Wave the magic wand with the A button and send the box to the CEO.
Swing the magic ax with the B button and send the box to the CFO.

CEO: He loves approving quotes!!
CFO: He loves counting the money in our bank account.
Greenbox: Request for quotation
Redbox: Billing request

It's really simple... but please don't send the wrong box, they will be damaged if they see documents they don't understand!
Oh, and it's dangerous to touch the box directly; it's extremely violent, so you'll have to use magic to deal with it.

Story mode

A single-player mode that follows Takeru's story at L.Planning.

1P or 2P High Score mode

The main mode of this work. A mode where two people work together, either single or by screen sharing, to aim for a high score.
We are planning a ranking function in the future.

4P Battle mode

Four employees might send documents all over the place using screen sharing, and sometimes they might make a mistake and hit someone on their team.
The last employee who survives is the winner.

Please have fun with Remote Play Together!

short_description: Hello World!! This game is based on the image of a Japanese arcade game from the 70's to early 80's where you could easily play by inserting 1 coin. The player will work hard at his sales job to save L.Planning, a company that has been reincarnated into another world.
